awd_titl_txt: Vehicular Traffic Modeling and Control in Mixed Manual and Automated Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Cutting-edge vehicle technologies such as Connected Vehicles and Automated Vehicles present unprecedented opportunities to drastically improve traffic operations and safety. These technologies can fundamentally change driver interactions and have enormous potential to remedy traffic phenomena known to be detrimental to traffic efficiency and stability. Among different types of Automated Vehicles technologies, Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control is particularly advantageous due to its unique ability to foster high performance, doubling (or more) roadway capacity and significantly improving flow stability. This research project seeks to shed light on the traffic congestion mechanisms in mixed streams of manual and high performance automated vehicles. It also aims to develop mitigation strategies to reduce traffic congestion by unprecedented levels, contributing to the nation's economic competitiveness and sustainable urban development. This project will engage in a range of integrated research, educational and outreach activities that will expand the knowledge obtained from this research to a broader audience. The activities include (i) developing simulation-based educational modules, (ii) disseminating results using driving simulator, and (iii) engaging undergraduate and graduate students in the research and education.

Traffic breakdown (onset of wide-spread congestion) is often triggered at freeway bottlenecks near merges and weaves. This phenomenon is characterized by high flow prior to breakdown, succeeded by a significant reduction in bottleneck discharge rate (known as "capacity drop"). The objectives of this research are to:  (1) shed light on the behavioral mechanisms underlying traffic breakdown at bottlenecks in mixed manual and Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control enabled vehicular environments and (2) develop theoretically-grounded control strategies to mitigate traffic breakdown and capacity drop. To better understand these mechanisms and enable vehicle-based control, this research will perform multi-scale analysis and modeling by linking microscopic features (driver characteristics, lane changes) to mesoscopic features (vehicle platooning) and eventually to macroscopic features (breakdown flow). This research will push the frontier of traffic flow research in the era of automated vehicles. Results from this research will advance our knowledge of congestion mechanisms, particularly around extended merge and weave bottlenecks. Moreover, control strategies will be developed based on the fundamental understanding of driving behavior to effectively mitigate traffic breakdown via vehicle-based control. Both proactive and reactive strategies will be developed at different levels of sophistication to enable implementation of robust control for select automation levels.

por.por_cntn:
Cutting-edge Connected Automated Vehicle (CAV) technologies present unprecedented opportunities to drastically improve traffic efficiency, stability and safety. These technologies can fundamentally change driver interactions and have enormous potential to remedy traffic phenomena known to be detrimental to traffic efficiency and stability before the arrival of full automation. Traffic breakdown (onset of wide-spread congestion) is one such phenomenon, often triggered at freeway bottlenecks near merges, diverges and weaves due to systematic lane changes. It is characterized by a significant reduction in bottleneck discharge rate (known as “capacity drop”), resulting in a diminished system throughput and an increased system delay. Furthermore, traffic instability can further lead to loss in system throughput. The overarching goal of this research was to shed light on the behavioral mechanisms surrounding traffic breakdown and traffic instability in mixed traffic of human-driven vehicles and CAVs, and to develop theoretically-grounded control strategies using CAVs to improve system throughput.

 

This project has contributed in three major aspects: (1) analysis and modeling of mixed traffic dynamics, (2) development of CAV control strategies, and (3) development of traffic management strategies. As part of (1), this research formulated base traffic operational capacity in mixed traffic in equilibrium, taking into account CAV penetration rate, micro/mesoscopic characteristics of vehicles (e.g., platoon size, spacing characteristics), and different lane policies to accommodate CAVs (e.g., exclusive CAV lanes, mixed-use lanes). A general formulation was developed to determine the valid domains of different lane policies and more generally, CAV distributions across lanes with respect to demand, as well as optimal solutions to accommodate AVs. Building on the base capacity in equilibrium, this research also investigated traffic dynamics related to traffic breakdown, capacity drop, and traffic stability, first focusing on human-driven vehicles and then extending it to mixed traffic. Specifically, this project developed a stochastic model for traffic breakdown, capturing various influencing factors at the individual vehicle level and traffic level. Capacity drop at extended merge, diverge and weave bottlenecks was also investigated analytically to better understand how spatially-distributed lane changes interact with one another and contribute to capacity drop. These investigations led to studies of mixed traffic dynamics and system throughput. These studies show that heterogeneity in preferred acceleration rate, desired speed, and car-following behavior change traffic properties in ways that can undermine traffic flow throughput.

 

Insights from the studies above inspired development of various CAV control strategies. Several approaches were explored, including tactical traffic theory based approach, control theory based approach (linear feedback/feedforward control, model predictive control), as well as physics-based approach based on the spring-mass-damper system concept. With the tactical traffic theory based approach, ideal CAV trajectories were designed with the system-level throughput and stability in mind to minimize the probability of traffic breakdown, improve system throughput, reduce the impact of lane changes on capacity drop, and improve traffic flow stability considering human-driven vehicle behavior. With the control theory based approach, vehicle control strategies were developed to address various uncertainties (in vehicle dynamics, communication, etc.) while guaranteeing local and string stability of a platoon consisting of pure CAVs or mixed vehicles. With the spring-mass-damper based system, control strategies focus on forming and recovering CAV platoons efficiently to maximize system throughput.

 

The insights from the analysis and modeling of traffic dynamics also inspired traffic management strategies, mainly through dynamic speed control of traffic, to minimize the probability of traffic breakdown and increase system throughput particularly through bottlenecks.  

 

In summary, the results of this research provide a better understanding of mixed traffic dynamics, models to describe them, and CAV vehicle control and traffic management strategies to improve traffic flow efficiency and stability. The results of this research have been disseminated through publications in high impact journals and presentations at conferences and academic institutions. One of the publications led to an award, Best Paper in Traffic Flow Theory, by AHB45 Traffic Flow Theory and Characteristics Committee of Transportation Research Board (TRB). Two papers were accepted and presented at the International Symposium on Traffic and Transportation Theory (ISTTT), a prestigious symposium in the field of traffic flow theory. The results have also been incorporated into two graduate courses. This research involved three PhD students and two postdocs.
